creator.name: Dastan Salmurzaev
creator.bio1: I went through a large number of interviews for a frontend developer position myself. I know how difficult it is to prepare when information is scattered across different sources.
creator.bio2: That's why on January 26, 2025 I launched ITLead ‚Äî a platform that brings everything you need in one place.
creator.bio3: Today the platform is used by {count}+ users from CIS countries, and I continue to develop it every day.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Everything you need to know about ITLead

what.question: What is ITLead?
what.answer: ITLead is a free platform for frontend interview preparation. We offer a structured knowledge base, practical tasks, and code checking tools.

different.question: What makes ITLead different from other interview prep platforms?
different.answer: We focus exclusively on real interview questions from top companies. All content is structured with detailed explanations and the ability to practice directly in the browser.

register.question: Do I need to register to use ITLead?
register.answer: You can view a lot of content without registration, but to track progress, save completed tasks, and access all features, we recommend creating a free account.

companies.question: Which companies' interview questions are included?
companies.answer: We include questions from interviews at companies like Google, Meta, EPAM, SoftServe, GlobalLogic, and many other top IT companies.

practice.question: Can I practice coding online?
practice.answer: Yes! We have a built-in IDE where you can write and run code directly in the browser with automatic solution checking.

updates.question: How often is new content added?
updates.answer: We add new content regularly - new questions, tasks, and articles appear every week.

beginners.question: Is ITLead suitable for beginners?
beginners.answer: Yes! We have content for all levels - from junior to senior developers. Material is structured from simple to complex.

ai.question: Why is this platform needed if there are different resources like AI?
ai.answer: AI is a great tool, but our platform provides verified, structured content specifically from real interviews. We know what they ask and how best to prepare.

introduction.title: ITLead - Platform for Frontend Interview Preparation
introduction.welcome: your reliable assistant in interview preparation!
introduction.description: We understand that preparing for a frontend developer interview can be challenging. Web technologies are constantly evolving, competition in the job market is growing, and it's important to be ready for all questions. That's why we created this platform to help you not only refresh your knowledge of key aspects of frontend development, but also gain practical experience in solving typical tasks that you might encounter in interviews.
introduction.platformDescription: is a platform that combines theoretical knowledge and practical tasks so you can prepare for interviews as effectively as possible.

component-lifecycle-methods-in-react.title: Component Lifecycle Methods in React
component-lifecycle-methods-in-react.content:
## What is Component Lifecycle? **Component lifecycle** in React is a sequence of stages that component goes through from its **creation** to **removal** from DOM. Lifecycle exists only for **class components**, but its behavior can be **replicated** using **hooks** in functional components. --- ## Lifecycle Stages Lifecycle is divided into **3 key phases**: | Phase | Description | |-------|-------------| | **Mounting** | Moment component appears in DOM | | **Updating** | Component update when changes occur | | **Unmounting** | Component removal from DOM | ## Mounting Phase Methods | Method | When called | |--------|-------------| | `constructor` | At component creation moment | | `static getDerivedStateFromProps` | Before render (rarely used) | | `render` | Required method, returns JSX | | `componentDidMount` | After mounting to DOM | ## Updating Phase Methods | Method | When called | |--------|-------------| | `static getDerivedStateFromProps` | When props update | | `shouldComponentUpdate` | Before re-render (can cancel it) | | `render` | At every update | | `getSnapshotBeforeUpdate` | DOM snapshot before update | | `componentDidUpdate` | After component update | ## Unmounting Phase Method | Method | When called | |--------|-------------| | `componentWillUnmount` | Before component removal from DOM | ## Functional Component Equivalents Hook functions allow replicating lifecycle behavior: | Class method | Hook in function | |--------------|-----------------| | `componentDidMount` | `useEffect(() => {}, [])` | | `componentDidUpdate` | `useEffect(() => {...}, [dep])` | | `componentWillUnmount` | `useEffect(() => { return () => {...} }, [])` | | `shouldComponentUpdate` | `React.memo()` + `useCallback`, `useMemo` | ## Hook Usage Example ```tsx import { useEffect } from "react"; function MyComponent() { useEffect(() => { console.log("Component mounting"); return () => { console.log("Component unmounting"); }; }, []); return
Hello!
; } ``` > **Tip:** In new projects it's better to use **functional components with hooks** ‚Äî they're simpler, more concise and recommended by React community.

virtual-dom.title: Virtual DOM in React
virtual-dom.content:
## What is Virtual DOM? **Virtual DOM** is a programming concept where a "virtual" representation of the UI is kept in memory and synced with the "real" DOM by a library such as React. ## Why Virtual DOM? Direct DOM manipulation is expensive. Virtual DOM allows React to: - **Batch updates** efficiently - **Minimize reflows and repaints** - **Optimize rendering** by comparing virtual trees - **Provide a simpler programming model** ## How It Works 1. React creates a **virtual representation** of the DOM in memory 2. When state changes, React creates a **new virtual DOM tree** 3. React **compares** (diffs) the new tree with the previous one 4. React **updates only the changed nodes** in the real DOM ## Example ```tsx function Counter() { const [count, setCount] = useState(0); return (

Count: {count}

); } ``` When `count` changes, React: 1. Creates new virtual DOM 2. Diffs with previous virtual DOM 3. Updates only the `

` text node in real DOM > **Tip:** Virtual DOM is not faster than direct DOM manipulation, but it makes React's declarative programming model possible and optimizes updates efficiently.

description.line1: Stop preparing blindly. Get access to the
description.line2: Master thousands of real technical questions with expert feedback.

debounce.primary: Correct use of 'this' context and closures. How would you modify this to handle an 'immediate' execution flag?
debounce.secondary: Good that you're clearing the timeout. Remember some interviewers will ask about memory leaks if 'fn' holds large references.

throttle.primary: Clean implementation using a boolean flag. How would you ensure the last call always executes after the limit ends?
throttle.secondary: Good use of closures for state preservation. Think about trade-offs between leading and trailing execution.

memoize.primary: Map is a great choice for cache. Be careful with JSON.stringify on complex objects or circular references.
memoize.secondary: Efficient lookup. In a real scenario, how would you implement an LRU eviction policy to prevent memory overflow?

questionVault.label: Middle+ Knowledge Base
questionVault.title: Relevant
questionVault.subtitle: We've selected the most popular questions asked in interviews for

react.query: Explain the difference between useMemo and useCallback. In what cases can their usage actually degrade performance?

js.query: What are closures and how do they help encapsulate data in JavaScript? Give a practical example.

backend.query: How to implement centralized error handling in Express.js through middleware for async operations?

fullstack.query: Explain the Dependency Injection concept in NestJS. How to properly organize module interaction through providers?

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Didn't find what you were looking for? Contact our technical support team anytime.

beginners.question: Is ITLead suitable for beginners or experienced developers?
beginners.answer: Both. We have basic algorithmic tracks for entry-level candidates and in-depth modules on distributed systems specifically for Senior, Staff, and Principal interviews.

aiMock.question: How does AI Mock interview work?
aiMock.answer: Our engine uses fast speech-to-text conversion and LLM-based evaluation to simulate a real interviewer. It assesses your logic, ability to explain trade-offs, and 'soft skills' under pressure.

cancel.question: Can I cancel my subscription at any time?
cancel.answer: Absolutely. We offer a transparent monthly plan with no lock-in periods. You can manage your billing directly from the dashboard.

relevant.question: Are the interview questions up-to-date?
relevant.answer: Yes. Our question database is updated weekly based on verified community reports about recent interviews at companies like Meta, OpenAI, and Stripe.

referrals.question: Does ITLead provide referral opportunities?
referrals.answer: Active participants at our 'Pro' level get access to an exclusive referral network, where verified mentors can recommend candidates directly to their internal hiring pipelines.

footer.description: Inspiring the next generation of engineers to build a better future, one interview at a time!
